person.note: The inscription is bilingual, Palmyrene and Greek. So in Palmyrene. The identification of the name is based on the Greek, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.
On this form see vol. 3, Aeleius (3) L/M, p. 452.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The contract is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
On this form see vol. 1, Africanus (1) L/M, p. 325, n. 2.
The name is deciphered in no. 1226, but a photograph of the inscription is reproduced in no. 1215, because it is found on the same cover as Elḥanan (1).
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Africanus [1]), p. 325, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
See above, n. 2.
Not the same as the previous. Though one is on an ossuary and one on an ossuary cover, the two do not fit.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Africanus [2]), p. 325, but not included in the statistics.
See above, n. 5.
See above, n. 6.
On Greek transliteration of Latin: the variant suffix and the single ν see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.3, p. 19.
In Greek – κλιβανάρις τρίτος Παλμύρας (Latin – Clibanarius – mounted soldier, third Palmyrene [division]). See the discussion in Clermont Gannaue, loc. cit.
I have now decided that the graffiti in the Tombs of the Prophets should be considered Jewish, see Introduction 6.4.1, and vol. 2, Introduction to Addendum.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

For all these versions see N. Sacks, The Mishnah with Variant Readings (Jerusalem 1975) 359 (Hebrew). The only version that makes any sense as a name is אנטינוס. On the interchange of ו and י as a scribal error see Introduction 2.7.1, or as reflecting another dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.1. On the short forms of the suffix in all versions of the name see Introduction 2.2.1.2.
This person is described in the text as בן אנטינוס (=Antonius’ son).

Appears in rabbinic literature as associating with the temple service, see Introduction 6.6. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (mistakenly under Antigonus [4] G/M), p. 264, but not included in the statistics.
In the Mishnah he is described העלה בכורות מבבל (brought first-borns [to Jerusalem] from Babylonia).
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
Both forms are found in the bowl. On the interchange of the א and ה suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25. On this suffix for Greek and Roman names see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. The editor thought this was the feminine Aurelia, but the masculine אביהן (their father) which follows it makes it unlikely. On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
Jewishness suggested based on grandfather’s name, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The contract is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. The transliteration is straightforward, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.

The tomb is pagan, but this part may have been sold to a Jew, as the name Hananiah (32) suggests, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Also, the deceased are presented in human form on their sarcophagi, and see Introduction 6.8.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
See above, n. 5.
The tomb is pagan, but this part may have been sold to a Jew, as his father’s name suggests, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
See above, n. 7.
On this form see vol. 3, Aurelius (14) L/M, p. 464.
This is a military list.
Jewishness may be suggested based on other name, but see Introduction 6.5.2.
This is the year Dura was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.2.
The emendation is suggested by the editor, see Introduction 2.1. On this form see above, n. 11.
See above, n. 12.
See above, n. 13.
See above, n. 14.
On the double consonant see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.3, p. 19. On the form Bonius see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.4, p. 19. On the transliteration of i with ε see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, p. 17.
Jewishness suggested by the name Samuel (44, 45) mentioned in the same burial inscription, but they need not be relatives, see Introduction 6.5.4.2.
Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.
On this form see vol. 1, Fulvius (1) L/M, p. 330, n. 2.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Fulvius [1]), p. 330, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

The transliteration is quite straightforward, see Introduction 2.2.1. The additional vowels are matters of pronunciation and dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2. For the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1.7, p. 24.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
On this form see vol. 1, Germanus (1) L/M, p. 332, n. 2.
In Greek – Παλμυρηνοῦ.
The inscription was found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.1.
This is the year in which Beit Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.1.

state.note: Chief of the synagogue in Edessa

person.note: In Syriac. Perhaps the Greek name Eumenes (Ε̓μένης) is intended.
In Aramaic – ܪܒ ܟܢܝܫܬܗܘܢ ܕܝܗܵܘܕܝܐ ܕܥܡܪܝܢ ܗܘܘ ܒܐܘܪܗܝ (head of the synagogue of the Jews who reside in Edessa [Urhi]).
Described in the text as ܝܗܘܕܝܐ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.
Was a contemporary of Julian the Apostate. These are his dates.
On this form see vol. 1, Julius (1) L/M, p. 332, n. 2.
Jewishness indicated by other name, see Introduction 6.5.
Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.

In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. The editor thought this was the feminine Julia, but the masculine אביהן (their father), which accompanies this name, makes it unlikely. For the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
Jewishness suggested based on grandfather’s name, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The contract is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

state.note: Aurelius (2) ʿAbbas (2), Ḥananiah (31)’s son, Martha (6)’s husband

person.note: In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. The transliteration is quite straightforward, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.

The tomb is pagan, but this part may have been sold to a Jew, as the name Ḥananiah (32) suggests, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Also, they are presented in human form on their sarcophagi, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
See above, n. 8.
See above, n. 9.
See above, n. 10.
In Georgian, see Introduction 2.8.5. The transliteration into Latin is taken from the index.
So in the in Georgian. In the Life of Saint Nino (D. M. Lang, Lives and Legends of the Georgian Saints [New York 1956], 27) he is from Karsani. This is obviously a place in Georgia.
Described in the text as “Hebrew,” see Introduction 6.1.
This person is described as having been witness to the death of Jesus and having brought his cloak from Jerusalem to Georgia. This is obviously a fictitious composition.
This is the date of the crucifixion, see previous note.

This is the reading of one editor of the inscription. For a completely different reading see under Uzi (1) B/M. The transliteration is quite straightforward, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.3.
Later editors doubt the reading suggested by the earliest editor of the text, see above, n. 2.
Date suggested by the editor, perhaps based on the assumption that this graffito was scribbled at the same time as the dedication inscriptions for the synagogue.

So in the prints and also in the Hamburg 169 Ms, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. The decision to identify it as this name is based on the next version. This version is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20.

So in most mss: Munich 95, Vatican 121 and NY – JTS ENA 2098.9, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. The transliteration is straightforward, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the י suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1.4, p. 24.
So in the Vatican 122 Ms, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. The extra י is probably a scribal error, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.1, p. 20.
In Aramaic – בר פיולי.
Appears in rabbinic literature as attending a rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Was a contemporary of Samuel (1), who died in 253 CE, according to ShGa § 161 CE, see Introduction 8.2.1.
The inscription is bilingual, Palmyrene and Greek. So in Palmyrene. For this transliteration see next note. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.
The inscription is bilingual, Palmyrene and Greek. So in the Greek. On this form see vol. 3, Publius (2) L/M, p. 534.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
This seems a straightforward transliteration of the name, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
This seems a straightforward transliteration of the name, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
See above, n. 2.
In Aramaic – מר.
See above, n. 3.
See above, n. 4.
So in the printed editions. The יו suffix looks like a declined Latin form, see e.g. vol. 3, Severus (3 & 4) L/M, p. 546.
So in the Munich 95 Ms. On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
So in the NY – Columbia X 893 T 141 and the Vatican 121 Mss. On the ון suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27.
Appears in rabbinic literature, and his son bears the title רב (Rav), see Introduction 6.6.2.
His son was a contemporary of Rav Ashi (2), who died in 427 CE, according to ShGa § 186, see Introduction 8.2.1.
So in the printed Vilna and Barko versions of the text, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. On the transliteration of v with ב see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 17.
So in the Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. See above, n. 2. On the fall of the second י see Introduction 2.3.5.4.
The text refers to a בר ביניתוס (son of Venetus).
In Hebrew – מלווה בריבית.
Appears in rabbinic literature in association with a rabbinic court, see Introduction 6.6.3. However, he is described as loaning money to Jews, an occupation shunned by the rabbis.
Was a contemporary of Rava (Abba [17]), who died in 352 CE, according to ShGa § 176, see Introduction 8.2.1.

div.note: Latin gentilium and cognomen, see RNGCL, 9, 289.
Latin cognomen, RNGCL, 231 and gentilium, RNGCL, 106.
Latin cognomen and praenomen, see RNGCL, 376.
